chron-entry.chron-text: The early Greeks migrated to the Balkan peninsula from north of the River Danube, displacing the Minoan civil­ization that had spread from Crete (Kríti) to the southern coast of modern Greece. They established independent states and colonized the coastal regions of the Mediterranean.
Foundation of the Greek state of Sparta, a military society which came to dominate the southern Peloponnese.
The first pan-Hellenic games were held, with athletes from all over the Aegean competing. The event is often cited as the first indication of a Greek national consciousness.
The city state of Athens (Athínai) developed the traditions of democracy.
Persian forces (which had already subjugated the Greek states of Asia Minor) landed at Marathon in Greece and were eventually defeated by the Athenians.
The Persians again invaded Greece. They advanced on Athens and burned down the city, but were eventually defeated at the Battle of Plataea.
The first Peloponnesian War was fought between Athens and Sparta.
The second Peloponnesian War ended with the defeat of Athens.
Philip II acceded to the throne in Macedon. His military campaigns ended the independence of the Greek city states.

Accession of Philip II’s son, Alexander III the Great’, who consolidated his father’s position in Greece and then proceeded to invade and conquer the Persian Empire, spread­ing Hellenic civilization as far as Egypt and the borders of India. Alexander died in 323 bc .
With the collapse of the Antigonid dynasty’s power outside Macedon proper, the Greek states proclaimed their independence with Roman patronage.
Macedon was finally conquered by Rome, and Greece effectively came under imperial rule.
The Roman Emperor, Constantine, re­named the city of Byzantium Constantinople (later İstanbul, Turkey—now known as Türkiye) and declared it his capital, the New Rome’.
Following the death of Theodosius I, who had made Christianity the official religion of the Empire, the Empire was divided into East (Byzantine’) and West.
Slavs invaded the Balkan peninsula.

The Great Schism’ effectively formalized the division of the Church into Catholic West (led by the Roman patriarch, the Pope) and Orthodox East (led by the Patriarch of Constantinople), reflecting the political and cultural division of the Empire.
The Fourth Crusade arrived in Constantinople and created the so-called Latin Empire of Constantinople’, dividing the Byzantine Empire into feudal states, ruled mostly by Frankish dynasties.
The Byzantine Emperor Michael VIII captured the Peloponnese from its Frankish rulers, gaining control of Constantinople in 1261.

Ottoman troops captured Constantinople, beginning a period of Islamic rule over Greece. Within the Ottoman Empire Orthodox Christians were to be grouped in the Rum millet (ethnoreligious community), headed by the Ecumenical Patriarch in Constantinople.
At the Battle of Lepanto, off the northern coast of the Peloponnese, the Venetians and Spanish defeated the Ottoman navy, ending its dominance of the Medi­terranean.
Venetian forces captured Corinth and Athens.
A rebellion in the Peloponnese, supported by Russia, and on Crete, was defeated.
Ottoman forces defeated a Russian-inspired rebellion in Epirus.

Three Greeks resident in Odessa (then in the Russian Empire, now Odesa, Ukraine) founded a movement in support of Greek independence, the Philiki Etairia (Friendly Society). Branches of the organization were established throughout Greece, meeting in secret.
Ali Pasha, the Ottoman governor of Ioannina, began a rebellion against central rule.
The Greek flag was raised at a monastery in the Peloponnese, beginning the War of Independence.
Ottoman forces suppressed a rebellion on Crete, which supported union with an independent Greek state.
Supporters of independence having captured much territory, including Athens, Greek independence was proclaimed at Epidaurus.
Internal differences within the independence movement meant the imperial forces were able to regain large portions of the territory they had lost, including Athens.
Ioannis Kapodistrias was elected President of Greece.
The Great Powers of France, Russia and the United Kingdom joined the conflict in support of Greek independence and defeated the Ottoman fleet at Navarino.
Russia declared war on the Ottoman Empire.
By the Treaty of Adrianople, which concluded the war between Russia and the Ottomans, the latter recognized Greek autonomy.
The Protocol of London, agreed by the three Great Powers, established Greece as a sovereign state.

Kapodistrias was assassinated and the Great Powers created a hereditary monarchy. In 1833 the Bavarian Prince Otto accepted the throne (as King Othon) and moved the capital (hitherto at Nafplion—now Nafplio) to Athens.
The Ottoman Empire formally recognized the independence of Greece.
King Othon convened a National Assembly, which drafted a Constitution providing for a bicameral parliament.
King Othon was deposed by the military and replaced by the Danish Prince William, who became King George I.
The UK officially ceded the Ionian Islands (a British protectorate since 1815) to Greece. A new Constitution, reducing monarchical powers, was enacted.
The Great Powers forced the Ottomans to cede Thessaly and part of southern Epirus to Greece.
Greece’s plans to annex Crete resulted in conflict with the Ottomans. Following a peace settlement, the island became an international protectorate under King George I.
The President of Crete’s assembly, Elef­therios Venizelos, declared the island to be in union with Greece.
Following a coup by the military in the previous year, Venizelos was elected Prime Minister of Greece.

The Treaty of London concluded the First Balkan War, in which a league of Bulgaria, Greece, Montenegro and Serbia removed the Turks from the bulk of their European possessions. Greece expanded north and throughout the Aegean, and Crete was united with the Kingdom.
The Treaty of Bucharest concluded the Second Balkan War. Bulgaria lost Macedonia, which was divided between Serbia and Greece.

Owing to a dispute about Greece’s alignment in the First World War, Venizelos (who supported the Entente Powers, of France, Russia, Serbia and the UK, whereas King Konstantinos—Constantine—I imposed a policy of neutrality) established a rival Government in Thessaloniki.
France and the UK ousted the King and imposed Venizelos as Prime Minister of the whole of Greece.

The Treaty of Neuilly ceded Bulgarian territory to Greece. The Allied Powers had also granted Greece permission to occupy the region of Smyrna (now the Turkish city of İzmir) on the coast of Asia Minor.
Venizelos was defeated in legislative elections. A new, royalist administration restored the monarchy’s power.

Turkish nationalists drove back Greek forces, which had advanced far into Anatolia, forcing them to evacuate Smyrna. Thousands of refugees fled to Greece, and aspirations for a greater Greece’ were ended.
The Treaty of Lausanne ordered the exchange of religious minorities in Greece and Turkey. Muslims resident in Greece resettled in Turkey, and more than 1m. Christians from Asia Minor moved to Greece.
The monarchy was abolished when King Konstantinos I was asked to abdicate by the military.
Venizelos was reappointed Prime Minister.
After a failed coup, a plebiscite approved the restoration of the monarchy and the accession of King George II.
King George II appointed Gen. Ioannis Metaxas as Prime Minister, resulting in the organization of industrial action by the Kommunistiko Komma Elladas (KKE—Communist Party of Greece).
Metaxas persuaded the King to impose a revised constitution, in accordance with which the legislature was dissolved.

During the Second World War, Italy’s leader, Benito Mussolini, demanded that Italian forces occupying Albania be permitted to pass through Greece; Metaxas refused this demand, resulting in an invasion of Italian forces.
Nazi Germany invaded Greece, which became subject to Bulgarian, German and Italian occupation. The King and his ministers fled into exile.
Greek and British forces liberated Greece. An agreement between the British and Soviet leaderships ensured that post-war Greece would not be part of the communist sphere of influence’.
Communist resistance groups launched an armed insurgency against the Government of Georgios Papandreou. Fighting continued until early 1945.

A general election in March resulted in victory for royalist parties. A referendum confirmed support for the restoration of the monarchy. Communist groups formed a Democratic Army, the confrontations of which with the official Greek army escalated into civil war.
The civil war ended, as communist forces were defeated.
A new Constitution was enacted, providing for a parliamentary democracy, with a monarch as head of state. The Ellinikos Synagermos (Greek Rally), led by Alexandros Papagos, won the general election.
Papagos died in office and was succeeded by Konstantinos Karamanlis, who dissolved the Ellinikos Synagermos and founded the Ethniki Rizospastiki Enosis (ERE—National Radical Union).
The ERE won an absolute majority of parliamentary seats in the general election, and again in 1958 and 1961.
Karamanlis resigned. In the resultant general election Georgios Papandreou’s Enosis Kentrou (Centre Union) won the greatest number of seats, although it failed to gain an absolute majority.

King Konstantinos II acceded to the throne on the death of his father, King Paul (who had succeeded George II in 1947). In further legislative elections, the Enosis Kentrou won an absolute majority of parliamentary seats.
A group of army officers seized power, imposing military rule. Political leaders were arrested. A general election, scheduled for May, was postponed indefin­itely.
Col Georgios Papadopoulos became Prime Minister. He assumed the foreign affairs portfolio in January 1970 and became Regent in March 1972.
Following a failed naval mutiny, the monarchy was abolished and Greece declared a republic, with Papadopoulos assuming the presidency in the following month.

Unrest among students at the National Polytechnic was violently suppressed by the army. Papadopoulos was ousted in an internal military coup led by Brig.-Gen. Demetrios Ioannidis. Lt-Gen. Phaedon Ghizikis was appointed President, and a largely civilian cabinet, led by Adamantios Androutsopoulos, was installed. However, effective power remained with Ioannidis.

Following an unsuccessful attempt to depose the President of Cyprus, Archbishop Makarios, and the subsequent failure to prevent the Turkish invasion and occupation of northern Cyprus, the Androutsopoulos Government collapsed. The military regime was unable to retain power and Karamanlis was asked to return from exile to form a Government of National Salvation.
Karamanlis’s new party, Nea Dimokratia (ND—New Democracy), won an absolute majority of parliamentary seats at the general election.
A proposal to restore the monarchy was defeated in a plebiscite. Michael Stassinopoulos, head of the Council of State, was appointed President.
A new Constitution was enacted, providing for a parliamentary republic with certain executive powers vested in the presidency. Konstantinos Tsatsos replaced Stassinopoulos as President.

ND was returned to power following legislative elections. The Panellínio Socialistiko Kinima (PASOK—Panhellenic Socialist Movement), led by Andreas Papandreou, became the second largest party in Parliament.
Karamanlis was elected President. Georgios Rallis succeeded him as premier.
Greece joined the European Community (EC, now European Union—EU).
In a general election, PASOK obtained an absolute majority in Parliament. Papandreou subsequently formed Greece’s first socialist Government.
Karamanlis resigned in protest at government plans to reduce presidential powers. He was succeeded by Christos Sartzetakis.
PASOK retained a majority of seats following elections to the Parliament.
Greece and Albania reopened their common frontier, closed since 1940. Greece renounced its claim to Northern Epirus, Albania.
Parliament approved constitutional amendments, reducing presidential powers.
Greece and Turkey signed a no war’ agreement, after a decade of increasing tensions, which had brought the countries close to open conflict in March 1987.
ND won the greatest number of seats in parliamentary elections, but failed to obtain an overall majority. An interim Government was formed in July.

No party obtained a majority at further legislative elections. Another coalition administration was formed, led by Xenofon Zolotas. However, this Government collapsed in February 1990 and an interim non-political cabinet was installed.
ND secured a one-seat majority in another round of elections, and was thus able to form a single-party Government, led by Konstantinos Mitsotakis. In May Karamanlis returned to the presidency.

Mitsotakis assumed responsibility for the foreign affairs portfolio in order to co-ordinate his Government’s opposition to attempts by the former Yugoslav territory of Macedonia to gain international recognition as the Republic of Macedonia, owing to fears of territorial claims on the Greek province of Macedonia. In March 1993 the Government accepted a United Nations (UN) proposal that the title the former Yugoslav republic of Macedonia’ (FYRM) be used temporarily, and that negotiations be pursued on a permanent name acceptable to both sides.
The loss of ND’s narrow majority in September precipi­tated a general election. PASOK won the largest number of seats and formed a Government, again led by Papan­dreou.
Konstantinos Stefanopoulos, leader of the small Komma Dimokratikis Ananeosis (Party of Democratic Renewal), was elected President by the legislature.

Relations between Greece and the FYRM, which had been subject to what was effectively a Greek trade embargo since February 2004, were normalized, following the implementation of agreements on access to the Greek port of Thessaloniki and alterations to the FYRM’s flag.
Andreas Papandreou resigned as Prime Minister. He was suc­ceeded by Konstantinos (Kostas) Simitis.

The Government complied with a US petition to withdraw Greek military vessels from the area surrounding Imia (Kardak), a small group of uninhabited islands in the Aegean Sea, following Turkish attempts to claim sovereignty.
PASOK, led by Simitis, won a majority of seats in legislative elections. A Government, similar in composition to the previous one, was subsequently formed.

Direct talks held in Madrid, Spain, between Simitis and the Turkish President, Süleyman Demirel, led Greece and Turkey to pledge not to use violence or the threat of violence to resolve bilateral disputes.

Following a severe earthquake in north-western Turkey, Greece provided financial and material as­sistance and renounced its veto on EU financial aid to that country. Turkey reciprocated in the following month when an earthquake in Athens left more than 60,000 people homeless.

Georgios Papandreou became the first Greek Minister of Foreign Affairs to visit Turkey since 1962. The two countries agreed to hold direct talks on their military presence in the Aegean region and signed a number of eco­nomic co-operation agreements.
In legislative elections, PASOK, again led by Simitis, retained a majority of parliamentary seats. A largely unchanged Government was formed three days later.

Greek police made the first arrests of suspected members of the extremist left-wing Epanastatiki Organosi Dekaefta Noemvri (17N—November 17 Revolutionary Organization), which had been responsible for more than 20 political assassinations since 1975.

The trial commenced of 19 suspected members of 17N. The two principal defendants, Alexandros Giotopoulos and Dimitiris Koufodinas, were accused of carrying out more than 1,000 criminal acts. In December four were acquitted owing to a lack of evidence. Giotopoulos, Koufodinas and four others were sentenced to life imprisonment, while eight defendants also received custodial sentences. One defendant received a suspended sentence.

Simitis announced his resignation as PASOK leader, and called a general election, declaring that an administration with a new mandate was necessary to address developments in Cyprus prior to that country’s admission to the EU, scheduled for May.
At the general election, Konstantinos (Kostas) Karamanlis’s ND secured 165 seats in Parliament, thereby removing PASOK, which retained 117 seats, from government. Karamanlis led a new administration.
The Prime Minister of Turkey, Recep Tayyip Erdoğan, began an official visit to Greece—the first by a Turkish premier in 16 years.
Karolos Papoulias, a member of PASOK and a former Minister of Foreign Affairs, was elected unopposed as President by the Parliament.

At elections to Parliament, ND was returned to power, securing 152 seats. PASOK won 102 seats, followed by the KKE (22), the Synaspismos Rizospastikis Aristeras (SYRIZA—Coalition of the Radical Left), with 14 seats and the Laikos Orthodoxos Synagermos (LAOS—Popular Orthodox Rally), with 10 seats. The rate of participation by the electorate was some 74.1%. Karamanlis subsequently established a new Government.
At elections to the European Parliament, PASOK and ND each secured eight seats, while the KKE 8.4% and LAOS each won two seats. The rate of participation was 52.6%.

PASOK secured victory in legislative elections, winning 43.9% of the votes cast and 160 seats, while ND received 33.5% and 91 seats. The KKE received 7.5% of the votes and 21 seats, LAOS 5.6% and 15 seats, and SYRIZA 4.6% and 13 seats. Karamanlis subsequently resigned as President of ND. He was succeeded by Antonis Samaras in November.
The appointment of a new PASOK Government, led by Georgios Papandreou (as Minister of Foreign Affairs as well as Prime Minister), was announced.

The adoption of an austerity budget by Parliament, following the revelation that the country’s budget deficit had been substantially understated by the previous administration, prompted a series of public protests and a national strike.
Parliament elected Papoulias to a further presidential term.

Police used tear gas forcibly to disperse a group of rioting protesters, following a demonstration in Athens that had been attended by up to 25,000 people. Further general strikes and protests against the austerity plans took place throughout the first half of the year.
Parliament adopted a new programme of spending reductions and tax increases, precipitating a large protest by trade union members in Athens, which degenerated into violent clashes.

The European Commission, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) and the Euro­pean Central Bank (ECB) reached agreement with Greece on a programme intended to stabilize the Greek economy, in accordance with which funding of €110,000m. would be provided over a period of three years, of which €80,000m. was to originate from the countries of the eurozone. Greece was required to undertake an extensive programme of austerity.
Prime Minister Papandreou implemented a wide-ranging government reorganization.

Papandreou again reorganized the Government. Georgios Papaconstantinou was replaced as Minister of Finance by Evangelos Venizelos, hitherto the Minister of National Defence, who also became a Deputy Chairman.

Parliament approved a new programme of austerity measures, amid a two-day national strike and violent protests outside the parliament building. On 2 July EU Ministers of Finance approved the disbursement of further lending, temporarily alleviating the threat of default.

EU heads of state and of government agreed, in principle, the terms of a new programme of support for Greece, providing, inter alia , for the disbursement of funds from the European Financial Stability Facility, lower rates of interest and extended repayment terms.

A summit of eurozone heads of state and of government resulted in a renegotiated fiscal plan for Greece (as the programme agreed in July was inadequate to prevent a Greek debt default). Papandreou initially committed to implementing the plan, which conditionally approved lending of €130,000m. for Greece. On 31 October, however, Papandreou announced that he intended to seek public endorsement of the fiscal proposals at a national referendum.

Papandreou announced his resignation. Five days later a new, cross-party, interim administration was installed, led by Lucas Papademos, a former Governor of the Central Bank and a former Vice-President of the ECB.
At the beginning of a widely observed 48-hour strike, LAOS withdrew its four representatives from the governing coalition and a PASOK deputy minister resigned, in protest against austerity measures.
Parliament approved new austerity measures, amid violent protests in Athens.

Eurozone Ministers of Finance approved the €130,000m. rescue plan agreed in October, with additional preconditions, including an undertaking by Greece to accept a permanent EU economic monitoring mission.

Greece completed a restructuring of its debt, thereby meeting another core condition for the second financial assistance package to be released. The agreement meant that most private creditors would accept losses of 53.5%, which would eventually reduce the country's public debt by €100,000m.

In legislative elections no single party won an overall majority in Parliament. ND obtained 108 seats and SYRIZA secured 52 seats, effectively supplanting PASOK as the main left-wing party, which won 41 seats. After attempts to form a governing coalition were unsuccessful, fresh elections were scheduled, and an interim administration was installed.

In the new legislative elections, ND won 129 seats. SYRIZA secured 71 seats, and PASOK won 33 seats. Four smaller parties shared the remaining seats, among them the traditionalist right-wing Anexartitoi Ellines (ANEL—Independent Greeks), with 20 seats, and the extreme nationalist Chrysi Avgi (Golden Dawn), which obtained 18.

Samaras, the President of ND, announced the formation of a new Government, comprising members of ND, as well as four independent politicians, nominated by PASOK and the small Dimokratiki Aristera (DIMAR—Democratic Left) party. Parliament approved the new Government on 8 July.

Despite further violent protests and strike action, new stringent austerity measures, including an increase in the retirement age, were narrowly adopted by Parliament. One ND and six PASOK deputies were subsequently expelled from their respective parties owing to their failure to support the programme, which DIMAR opposed.

The EU-IMF-ECB `troika’ reached agreement on the disbursement of funds and on further concessions for the reduction of Greece’s debt. On 13 December the troika confirmed the agreed measures, and the delayed EU tranche of €34,300m. was subsequently disbursed.

Following the withdrawal of DIMAR earlier in the month, Samaras announced a reorganized Government. PASOK leader Venizelos returned to the Government as Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Foreign Affairs.

International lenders agreed to the disbursement of €4,800m. in aid to Greece, after the Government agreed to implement further large-scale public sector dismissals demanded by the troika. Greece was to receive a further €2,000m. from national central banks and the ECB.

A far-left activist was killed by a member of Chrysi Avgi in Athens. Police raided the headquarters of the party. At least 10 members of Chrysi Avgi were arrested in connection with the murder. Later in the month two senior police officers were obliged to resign owing to suspected connections to the organization.

A total of 19 members of Chrysi Avgi, including its leader, Nikolaos Michaloliakos, and six parliamentary deputies, were arrested. Michaloliakos and three of the deputies were subsequently detained on charges of organizing a criminal group. In October Parliament voted to remove the parliamentary immunity from prosecution from the deputies.

Parliament voted in support of suspending state funding to any political party that was associated with criminal activity. Most legislative representatives of ND, PASOK, SYRIZA and DIMAR voted in favour of the measure, while the deputies of Chrysi Avgi left the parliamentary chamber shortly before the vote, and those of the KKE and ANEL abstained.
The suspension of state funding (which was to have amounted to almost €900,000 annually) to Chrysi Avgi entered into effect.

At elections to the European Parliament SYRIZA secured six seats, ND obtained five seats, while Chrysi Avgi won three. A recently formed left-wing alliance led by PASOK, Elia—Dimokratiki Parataki (Olive Tree—Democratic Realignment) obtained two seats. A party recently formed by TV presenter Stavros Theodrakis, which supported the introduction of greater democracy in EU structures, To Potami (The River) also obtained two seats, as did the KKE, while ANEL won one seat. The rate of participation was 58.2%.
A government reorganization was implemented. Yannis Stournaras resigned as Minister of Finance, to become Governor of the Bank of Greece. He was succeeded by Gikas Hardouvelis.
Parliament was dissolved, after it failed to elect a new President on three successive occasions.

In the legislative elections, SYRIZA secured victory, with 36.3% of the votes cast and 149 seats (narrowly short of a majority), its support having increased substantially in response to its anti-austerity programme, while ND’s representation declined sharply, to 27.8% of the votes and 76 seats. Chrysi Avgi and To Potami each received 17 seats, the KKE obtained 15 seats, ANEL 13 seats. PASOK, experiencing a substantial loss of support, also obtained 13 seats. The leader of SYRIZA, Alexis Tsipras, reached a coalition agreement with ANEL (which, despite its ideological dissimilarity with SYRIZA, also opposed austerity measures). Tsipras’ Government, largely comprising SYRIZA members, was formed two days later. Yannis Dragasakis was appointed Deputy Prime Minister, while Yanis Varoufakis became Minister of Finance.
Parliament elected Prokopis Pavlopoulos as President. He was inaugurated on 13 March.

The Government presented a revised policy programme, which included commitments to combat tax evasion, corruption, and to implement labour reforms, although other pre-election pledges, such as the creation of jobs and a large increase in the minimum wage, were deferred. Greece was subsequently granted a four-month extension of its bailout programme.
The trial commenced of 69 Chrysi Avgi members, including Michaloliakos and former deputies, on charges of organizing and participating in a criminal group, and of weapons offences.
Greece imposed capital controls.

Greece defaulted on a delayed loan repayment to the IMF, becoming the first developed economy ever to do so, after the ECB refused to extend the existing bailout agreement. At midnight, without an agreement in place, Greece formally exited the bailout.

In a referendum, some 61.3% of the participating electorate voted to reject the implementation of conditions demanded (and subsequently withdrawn) by the country’s creditors in return for the restructuring of Greece’s international debt. One day after the referendum Varoufakis announced his resignation. He was replaced as Minister of Finance by Euclid Tsakalotos. On the same day Samaras resigned as leader of ND. ND, PASOK and To Potami agreed to support the Government in new negotiations with the lenders.
Greece requested new lending under the EU’s European Stability Mechanism (ESM).

A euro summit, principally comprising heads of state and of government of the eurozone and the President of the European Commission, reached provisional agreement to commence negotiations on new lending, which would be subject to the implementation of additional austerity measures.

Amid reports that the IMF considered the EU’s proposed conditions for additional lending unfeasible for Greece, owing to its levels of public debt, and amid violent anti-austerity protests in Athens, the Parliament gave initial approval to a new EU deal.

Tsipras reorganized his cabinet, notably removing a minister opposed to Greek membership of the euro. Banks (closed since 28 June) reopened three days later, although capital controls remained in place.
The new, three-year bailout agreement, providing for up to €86,000m. in financial assistance, was approved by Parliament.

The ESM Board of Directors authorized the first tranche of lending, worth €26,000m. (of which €16,000m. was to be used for financing the budget and servicing debt, and the remainder was allocated to fund possible bank recapitalization). As many SYRIZA deputies refused to support the agreement, the Government resigned, and Tsipras scheduled parliamentary elections for the following month.

In the legislative elections, SYRIZA won 35.5% of the votes cast and 145 seats. ND secured 28.1% of the votes and 75 seats, Chrysi Avgi 7.0% and 18 seats, an alliance of PASOK and DIMAR 6.3% and 17 seats, and the KKE 5.6% and 15 seats. To Potami received 4.1% of the votes and 11 seats, and ANEL won 3.7% of the votes and 10 seats. A rate of voter participation of 56.6% was recorded.
Tsipras assumed the leadership of a renewed coalition Government, in which Tsakalotos retained the post of Minister of Finance.
Parliament approved new austerity reforms. Two deputies of the ruling coalition who had voted against the measures were expelled, reducing the Government’s parliamentary majority.

An EU agreement was signed with Turkey, providing for refugees and other migrants travelling to Greece to be returned to Turkey if they were considered not to be in immediate need of international protection (the EU was to accept one Syrian refugee from within Turkey for each migrant returned to that country, and to provide funding of some €6,000m.). The agreement began to be implemented in April.

Parliament voted in favour of a government proposal to amend legislation on national elections, abandoning the existing award of an additional 50 seats to the first-placed party, instead adopting a system of proportional representation. (The law did not come into effect for the 2019 elections, as it did not receive approval by the required qualified majority.)
Tsipras announced a government reorganization.

One day after a national strike in protest against continuing austerity, Parliament approved new fiscal and structural reforms to taxes, pensions and the labour market, with the aim of securing approval of a further loan disbursement. Violent protests ensued.

Following a meeting of eurozone Ministers of Finance, also attended by Managing Director of the IMF Christine Lagarde, agreement was reached in principle on the next stages of the bailout arrangement, alleviating the risk of default by Greece on repayments due in July, and providing for the participation of the IMF in the rescue programme, by means of a 14-month precautionary stand-by arrangement. In July the IMF confirmed its willingness to contribute €1,600m. to the EU-led bailout programme for Greece although, in accordance with the agreement reached in June, the IMF would contribute no funds until the country’s EU creditors agreed to increased debt relief, owing to concerns about the sustainability of Greece’s debt burden.
Erdoğan, now the President of Turkey, made an official visit to Greece, representing the first such visit by a Turkish head of state for over 60 years.

Parliament approved measures demanded by Greece’s international creditors in exchange for further support. In addition to fiscal and energy market reforms, the legislation provided for a controversial labour amendment, which required unions to secure the support of 50% of their members before announcing a strike, prompting a protest by some 6,000 demonstrators in Athens.
Tsipras reorganized his cabinet. Dimitris Vitsas was appointed as Minister of Migration Policy.

Tsipras and his FYRM counterpart, Zoran Zaev, signed the so-called Prespa agreement, providing for the eventual renaming of the FYRM as the Republic of North Macedonia, as a result of which Greece would end its obstruction of the country’s applications for membership of the EU and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO). The agreement required parliamentary approval in both countries, and was also subject to endorsement by referendum in the FYRM. The proposal met with substantial opposition in Greece, and on 16 June the parliamentary faction of ND unsuccessfully brought a motion of no confidence against Tsipras. Demonstrations against the proposed name (which some regarded as irredentist) also took place in Athens, attended by around 5,000 protesters.

Eurozone Ministers of Finance reached agreement on debt relief for Greece, extending repayment terms by 10 years on bailout lending totalling almost €100,000m., as the country made preparations for its formal departure from the financial rescue programme. Under the terms of the debt relief accord, Greece agreed to maintain a primary budget surplus (excluding debt repayments), of 3.5% of GDP until 2022, with a long-term target of 2.2%.

At an emergency meeting of the Government Tsipras announced that he considered himself `politically responsible’ for the consequences of wildfires near Athens, which resulted in over 90 deaths. In early August the Minister of Civil Protection resigned.
Greece formally exited the third bailout programme, following the disbursement of a final tranche of ESM financial assistance for Greece, amounting to €15,000m., on 6 August.

A government reorganization took place, in which, however, most principal ministers were retained. Michalis Kalogirou, hitherto the Secretary-General of the Government, was appointed Minister of Justice, Transparency and Human Rights.

Nikos Kotzias resigned the foreign affairs portfolio, following disagreements with Minister of National Defence and ANEL leader Panos Kammenos, who strenuously opposed the Prespa agreement; Tsipras subsequently assumed the role in an acting capacity

Adm. Evangelos Apostolakis, hitherto chief of the Hellenic National Defence General Staff, was sworn in as Minister of National Defence, replacing ANEL leader Panos Kammenos who had resigned the previous day, after announcing his party’s withdrawal from the coalition Government. Also on 14 January Kammenos expelled ANEL Minister of Tourism Elena Kountoura, who had pledged her support for the Government, from ANEL’s parliamentary group.
A rally attended by an estimated 60,000 people in opposition to the agreement with the FYRM took place in Athens, with clashes between demonstrators and police.

With another protest taking place in Athens, Parliament endorsed the Prespa agreement, with 153 votes cast in favour and 146 against (dissident ANEL members supported SYRIZA in the vote, while ND refused to support the agreement). It was signed into law shortly afterwards.
Greece was the first NATO member state to ratify the FYRM’s NATO accession protocol, allowing the name change as the Republic of North Macedonia to enter into force officially four days later.

Eurozone Ministers of Finance approved the release of an initial payment of post-bailout debt relief funding, amounting to €970m., after Parliament adopted a new, more stringent framework for the protection of primary residences from foreclosure; the payment had been due in early March.

ND secured eight seats in the European Parliament, while SYRIZA won six seats. A PASOK-led coalition, Kinima Allagis (Movement for Change), won two seats, as did the KKE and Chrysi Avgi. The populist Elliniki Lisi (Greek Solution) won one seat. The rate of participation was 58.7%.

The second round of voting in local and regional elections took place, in which opposition candidates performed strongly. ND candidate Kostas Bakoyannis was elected Mayor of Athens, defeating the candidate supported by SYRIZA, Nasos Iliopoulos.

Following the reduced support for SYRIZA in both the regional and local elections and the elections to the European Parliament, Tsipras announced his resignation and scheduled an early general election.

Early legislative elections took place, as scheduled, in which ND emerged as the leading party, securing a majority in the legislature, with 39.9% of the votes cast and 158 seats. SYRIZA, which attracted 31.5% of the votes and won 86 seats, was therefore removed from power. Kinima Allagis was third-placed, with 8.1% of the votes and 22 seats, followed by the KKE, with 5.3% of the votes and 10 seats. Two recently formed parties also obtained seats. Elliniki Lisi won 3.7% of the votes and 10 seats and the left-wingMetopo Evropaikis Realistikis Anypakois (MeRA25—European Realistic Disobedience Front), led by Varoufakis, won 3.4% of the votes and nine seats.

ND leader Kyriakos Mitsotakis was sworn in as Prime Minister. He announced the composition of his new Government on the same day. The former President of the Council of State (the country’s highest judicial organ) and interim Prime Minister for a period of one month in 2012, Panagiotis Pikrammenos, was appointed as Deputy Prime Minister. Nikos Dendias was appointed Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Christos Staikouras became Minister of Finance. The Government was sworn in on 9 July.
Economic reforms presented by Mitsotakis were approved by Parliament, despite union-led protests and industrial action, which had taken place from late September.
The leaders of Greece, Cyprus and Israel signed a tripartite agreement for the construction of a natural gas pipeline, the Eastern Mediterranean pipeline (EastMed).
Following a surge in migrant arrivals, Mitsotakis re-established a Ministry of Migration and Asylum; Panagiotis (`Notis’) Mitarakis was appointed to the post.
Parliamentarians elected Katerina Sakellaropoulou, hitherto the President of the Council of State, as the country’s President, after a single round of voting.

The Turkish Government announced that it would not prevent migrants from crossing its borders into Europe (following an upsurge in fighting in the Syrian Arab Republic, in which more than 30 Turkish soldiers were killed). Greek border guards subsequently fired tear gas to repel large numbers of migrants attempting to cross the border near the north-eastern town of Kastanies and the authorities announced the suspension of asylum applications.

In response to an escalation in cases of COVID-19, which was first confirmed in Greece on 26 February, educational institutions were closed; six days later commercial businesses were closed, and a quarantine was announced for those arriving into the country. From 23 March all non-essential travel and movement was prohibited.
Sakellaropoulou was inaugurated as President.
National lockdown measures imposed in response to COVID-19 began to be eased; primary schools and kindergartens reopened on 1 June.
Minister of Foreign Affairs Dendias and his Italian counterpart signed an agreement establishing an exclusive economic zone (EEZ) between Greece and Italy.

Parliament approved legislation under which demonstrations were to be restricted, or banned if they were considered by the authorities to threaten public safety; a rally by around 10,000 people was staged outside the parliamentary building to protest against the measures, which were criticized by human rights groups, and there were clashes with police.
Turkey announced plans to conduct hydrocarbons exploration activities near the Greek island of Kastellorizo, just off the coast of Turkey, prompting a formal protest from Greece.

The Ministers of Foreign Affairs of Greece and Egypt signed an agreement in the Egyptian capital, Cairo, creating an EEZ for hydrocarbons drilling rights between the two countries (in accordance with the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea—UNCLOS); Dendias’s claim that the agreement nullified a 2019 accord between Turkey and Libya (reached in violation of the UNCLOS) was rejected by Turkey and Libya.
A collision between Greek and Turkish frigates took place in the contested Mediterranean waters after Greece deployed navy vessels, increasing tensions.

Fire destroyed Europe’s largest refugee camp, on Lesbos. Designed to accommodate 3,000 people, it had been home to around 13,000 refugees, living in poor conditions. In mid-June 2021 four Afghan men were convicted of arson and sentenced to 10 years’ imprisonment.

The Athens Court of Appeal ruled that the leadership of Chrysi Avgi was guilty of running a criminal organization, while others were found guilty of various charges linked to Chrysi Avgi, including involvement in criminal violence. Chrysi Avgi leader Michaloliakos and several prominent former parliamentary deputies, on trial since 2015, were subsequently sentenced to 13 years’ imprisonment; 12 other former deputies were sentenced to prison terms of between five and 10 years, while a supporter of Chrysi Avgi was sentenced to life imprisonment for murder in 2013.
In response to increasing numbers of cases of COVID-19, new lockdown measures were introduced in an attempt to contain the pandemic. A vaccination programme commenced on 27 December.
An EU summit meeting resulted in an agreement by EU leaders to impose targeted sanctions against Turkey for its activities in the Eastern Mediterranean.
Mitsotakis effected a minor government reorganization, as part of which Makis Voridis was appointed as the new Minister of the Interior.

Representatives from Greece and Turkey met in İstanbul, Turkey, for exploratory talks to address the maritime disputes (the first such meeting since regular discussions had been suspended in 2016). However, in late February the Turkish Government accused Greece of deploying fighter jets to harass its research vessel.

Greece hosted a so-called Friendship Forum in Athens, attended by ministers responsible for foreign affairs from Egypt, Cyprus and the Gulf states of Bahrain, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates (and from France, remotely), with the stated aim of strengthening regional co-operation and security.

Following a series of wildfires in July and August, Mitsotakis reorganized his cabinet. Panagiotis (Takis) Theodorikakos, the former Minister of the Interior, replaced Minister of Citizen Protection Michalis Chrysochoidis. Vassilis Kikilias assumed the tourism portfolio, replacing Theocharis (Harry) Theocharides, and Kikilias was succeeded as Minister of Health by Athanasios Plevris. Mitsotakis also created a new Ministry of Climate Crisis and Civil Protection, led by former Cypriot MEP Christos Stylianides.

Following the Russian invasion of Ukraine on 24 February, Mitsotakis and Erdoğan met in İstanbul, and agreed to attempt to increase co-operation and foster improved relations. However, tensions subsequently re-emerged.

Mitsotakis addressed a joint session of the US Congress, in the first such address by a Greek leader. Without making overt reference to Turkey, he urged Congress against the sale of military equipment to that country, warning that such action could further destabilize the Eastern Mediterranean. Erdoğan consequently withdrew Turkey from further bilateral talks with Greece.

Amid a scandal over illicit surveillance that had led to the resignation of the Director of the National Intelligence Service (NIS), Mitsotakis made a televised statement denying knowledge of the illicit surveillance of PASOK-KINAL leader Nikos Androulakis; the NIS had been brought under the direct control of Mitsotakis after he took office in 2019.
A parliamentary motion of no confidence in Mitsotakis’ Government, brought by SYRIZA, was defeated, with 143 votes in favour and with 156 votes against.

A passenger train travelling from Athens to Thessaloniki collided with a freight train north of Larissa, killing 57 people and injuring more than 80. The Minister of Infrastructure and Transport, Kostas Karamanlis (a nephew of the former Prime Minister), resigned on 1 March, together with the head of the railway operating company.
President Sakellaropoulou approved a request by Mitsotakis to dissolve Parliament and legislative elections were scheduled for 21 May.

In the parliamentary elections, ND secured 40.8% of the votes cast (and improved its performance compared with 2019, when it received 39.9%). However, under amendments to electoral law passed in 2016, and which had entered into effect for the first time, ND had failed to attract sufficient support to enable it to form a majority government. SYRIZA secured 20.1% of the votes, while PASOK-KINAL was third-placed, with 11.5% of the votes. A caretaker Government took office on 26 May, and new elections were scheduled for 25 June.

A fishing vessel bound for Italy and carrying up to 750 irregular migrants, many of them Pakistani nationals, sank in international waters some 80 km from the Greek coast. Over 100 people were rescued, but there were 82 confirmed deaths and over 500 people remained missing, and were presumed to have drowned. In late July the EU announced that it was to carry out an investigation into the conduct of Frontex, the EU’s border control and coastguard agency, on the day of the sinking, amid conflicting reports as to whether the Greek authorities had responded appropriately to the crisis.

New legislative elections took place. ND secured 40.6% of the votes cast and 158 seats, under a reinstated system that awarded additional seats to the winning party. SYRIZA secured 17.8% of the votes and 4
7 seats, while PASOK-KINAL won 11.8% of the votes and 32 seats. Mitsotakis was again nominated as Prime Minister, and his new Government was sworn in on 27 June.

Amid a heatwave affecting large parts of Europe, wildfires broke out at several mainland and island locations in Greece. Rhodes was reported to be the most severely affected, with the declaration of a state of emergency and large-scale evacuation efforts continuing for days, during the country’s main tourist season.
